/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Thanks for this! Do you have a quick how-to so I could try it out locally?

I'm not entirely sure how to evaluate this change.  It's not such an egrigious burden to ask a small group of maintainers to ingore a few extra files in bin and etc; but I don't see how we could commit to "maintaining" them in any real sense.

As it sits, to me, this doesn't look like a complete change; I imagine the whole thing would make more sense adding the example uwsgi.ini files under the doc tree, like we do for saio example configs (another opinionated deployment config) along with some updates in doc/source/apache_deployment_guide.rst

The ultimate goal here isn't just to document how things should be done in production, but to make swift switch to uwsgi for its testing, so it gets closer to a real production environment. This patch is just the first step in this direction.

Note that currently, the object server cannot be set to use uwsgi, because it doesn't really comply to the RFC, and therefore only Eventlet is working correctly. This IMO should somehow be addressed at some point, as running a Python server using Eventlet goes half the speed as with uwsgi. Indeed, in production, we saw half the load on (very) busy servers.

Intentionally one IP address of a port to make the control granularity small. If user want to let all IPs of a port to have SNAT access, just add the IPs to the list of internal_cidrs with /32 prefix.

both those cases can be done by reusing address groups and IMHO it would be good to reuse that new feature which we added recently to neutron. Also if L38 is "per IP address" then it also can be covered by address group.

I still don't see any real reason why not to use it here. IMO problems which You mentioned with e.g. validation or dependencies between modules can be solve by notifications mechanism which we are using a lot in Neutron and which works pretty fine for us.
The SG were not done that way since the beginning but I don't think this is argument to not do it here, if we already have address groups in place. I think we should reuse resources as much as possible and IMHO that is perfect case for it.

I do not want to make this plugin to interact with others beyond L3 router plugin. Everything I want is to make things simple in this plugin. I can image if we mixed the address scope here, users will complain:
1. I want to set a SNAT rule for a router, but I need to create one address group. (problem of API complexity)
2. I want to create a SNAT rule, but why I can not reuse a address group. （problem of resource relevance）
3. I want to update a SNAT rule, but I need to show the `Elastic Snat` first to find the address group ID, and the update the address group. (problem of API complexity)
4. I have tons of `Elastic Snat`, but I also have tons of address group. (problem of API performance)
5. I list the tons of `Elastic Snat`, and I need to join query with tons of address group. (problem of API performance)

Everytime a user wants to try this, we need to teach them other things about `what is address group` and `how to use address group`. But finally, the user says: OK, it's just a list of IPs/CIDRs, why I can not directly set it.

For each router with its connected subnets, the cidrs (or ips) to create SNAT rule for will be very different. In the real production cloud environment, the SNAT rule will most likely evolve into 1-1 relationship to "address group". Because the CIDRs of subnets and the requirements for SNAT will be various for different users. So, there is no foreseeable solution to solve those 5 problems I mentioned above.
This not only increases the complexity of the API, but I don't think this kind of forced binding relationship has benefit. Make this independent and simple is the only thing I insist here.

My idea is make this plugin independent to not involve with any other services.

The ``internal IP``, ``subnets`` or ``a range CIDR of IPs`` for SNAT are all under a router for this plugin, it will check these inputs:
1. if IP or CIDR is under the router's subnets 
2. if the subnet is connected to the router
3. if the subnets connected to router has these IPs
4. if IPs or subnets has `Elastic Snat`, the connected subnets can not be removed

If we mix address group here, things will get complicated. Firstly a binding between address group and `Elastic Snat` should be added which is used to represent the input here. Secondly, `address group` update needs to verify if there are `Elastic snats` using it to prevent address out of router connected subnets. From the table [1], the addresses attribute has no relationship to router. Then for this plugin, it needs to cover these actions like 'address add/update/delete', not only the `Elastic Snat` itself, but also `address group` binding to it. Finally, for this input here, it is ordered. I don't know if the address of `address group` can place it in the order for the user's requirements.

So, if you insist on using address group, IMO, maybe we can refactor to use it someday like security group do now as a new RFE. Since security group does not use it from the begining.

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/neutron-specs/specs/victoria/address-groups-support-in-security-group-rule.html#new-address-groups-api

I don't agree with that. We have that concept of the groups of IPs which is address group already. It has some validation and can be potentially improved somehow in the future. And IMO we should reuse it in other places where it fits. And that is such case IMO.

> You may treat that "provider:network_type" is an alias of "provider:physical_network". There is no rule to limit that one "provider:physical_network" cloud not have two aliases.

right, but each physnet should correspond to a separate bridge - otherwise it doesn't make sense. And this is current assumption in code. Also if bridges are not unique we need to verify vlan_ranges are not intersecting, flat is not conflicting with vlan on same bridge, etc. All this leads to spaghetti code.

>

Because, if some cloud still insist to remain that 1:1 relationship, just keep all map setting as it is. But for some others, this change make the N:1 relationship available. I understand and agree with the use case but I think it should be addressed on host networking configuration level.

Host networking configuration is usually performed by OpenStack installer system using templates, so this shouldn't be an operator's headache. Also I'm not sure single bridge with many rules is simpler to debug that several bridges with specific rules. Still my main concern is that 'physical_network' term (and hence logic) will be compromised in neutron

Sorry, I'm not sure which part is confused. {"external": br-vlan, "user": br-vlan}, this is achivable in real world, external_vlan=4000 and user_vlan=1000-3000 can be set for one single port in TOR for some hosts, because they have only one physical NIC. For others, if NICs are enough, it can be separated. Two logical type of network are working together on one physical, for now I did not see any foreseeable problems.

So, may I have your opinions on how to deal with such production issue?

You may treat that "provider:network_type" is an alias of "provider:physical_network". There is no rule to limit that one "provider:physical_network" cloud not have two aliases.

This work is coming from an real deployment scenario, I'm not sure why this is not acceptable. Because, if some cloud still insist to remain that 1:1 relationship, just keep all map setting as it is. For that overlapping vlans, I don't know how it can work in a single NIC host. If there is one single NIC, this means it can only access one "provider:physical_network", but this approach can give clouds an option to map two or more local "provider:network_type" to one. This is a very common usecase. Because, in real production deployment, it is almost impossible to set a host in TOR with more than one (underlay/physical) VLAN network plane, aka two or more sets of 4096 vlan_IDs can be consumed, configuration complexity will increase dramatically.

specs/train/probe-api-and-agent-extensio.message: It might be clearer to say "we frequently encounter ssh failures"

My problem with this proposal is that it turns Neutron into a monitoring system.  The division of responsibilities has always been:

- neutron: this link is supposed to be up
- monasca: this link is actually up; I tested it

You can substitute any other kind of monitoring system instead of monasca there, but the point remains true: Neutron's goal is to orchestrate the configuration of the system, not to healthcheck all the resources all the time.  I see this proposal taking Neutron away from what it is good at, and trying to make it a general purpose do-everything solution rather than optimizing it to be the best at the tasks for which it was intended.

IMO, you are overthinking about this, it is a simple detecting API, no persistent process resources, no extra RPC or notification to monitor system. And this does not report any data to any data collector. It only returns the detect result to user by API response.
Do you mean "specific" here?  The word "statutory" means "enacted, regulated, or imposed by a legal authority" and doesn't really apply unless the commands are dictated by national laws.
I'm not a native English speaker, here my thought is to allow the user only run some defined  (or hard code, or configured) commands, not any commands from API.

So if I understand the neutron-debug functionality correctly, it calls neutron APIs to set up a port and interface on a specific subnet and plug it in.  Are you saying that when this funtionality is in use all VMs would have an additional port for use for this monitoring/backdoor access?

Basically right, maybe you can enjoy the neutron-debug tool first:
http://paste.openstack.org/show/752395/

Looking at the code [1] the probe is just a port.  If an instance is not up yet, how would an additional port help you determine that more effectively than the primary port already assigned to it?

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/neutron/debug/debug_agent.py#L44-L66

It is irrelevant for any resource not involved to the probe mechanism. This means, probe can be created at any time, WHEN you want to detect the network resource connectivity, you can use it. Your concern is the `when`, the users or the CI tests should take care about when they try to use such probe detecting. For instance, when port is ACTIVE status, or when VM is ACTIVE status. A more interesting use case is when users try to shutdown an instance, it can use such mechanism to detect if it is real powered off.

neutron/conf/common.py.message: Why would someone prefer to disable it in a DVR deployment?

1. For some deployment, they may not rely on the dvr local router to do data proxy. Then they can disable this.
2. Some deployment may not needs to wait the networking is done, such as they set "vip_plug_is_fatal = False", then this is not usable as well.
3. For large scale resources, or VM booting storm, this may cause some potential performance problem. Give a chance for those deployment to not wait on this check.

But uncommon use case is that one subnet is connected to two routers. And VM's port has two IPs from this subnet. And the default route is point to the second one. For instance:
* subnet1 range 192.168.1.0/24;
* 192.168.1.1 used for router1 as gateway IP
* 192.168.1.254 used for router2 as gateway IP
* subnet1 change the default route to 192.168.1.254
* users VM has fixed IPs 192.168.1.100 and 192.168.1.200

Then we should check the router2 is up.

The port under a dvr router should be retrieved in a loop in l3 agent side, then send the provisioning_complete, otherwise, things will be really complicated. IMO, it will be something like this:

This is a basic conclusion after IRC talking.

'is_router_up' will not be necessary to call anymore, as you recommended, it will be something like this:
1. port is created/updated
2. l3_dvrscheduler_db adds L3 provisioning_component for the port
3. l3 agent setup the router
4. l3 agent call neutron server (l3_plugin) says one router is up
5. l3 (dvr) plugin find out the router related L2 ports, remove L3 provisioning_component for them

But a race condition may happen:
1. port1 and port2 are from same subnet and same dvr router1, and will be setup at same host1.
2. port1 created L3 the provisioning_component
3. router1 is up at one host1
4. port2 is trying to create L3 the provisioning_component
5. L3 plugin will find/remove all router1 related L3 provisioning_component (race condition)
6. port2 is created L3 provisioning_component (race condition)
7. router is up at that host1, port2 will have no way to remove the L3 provisioning_component

So, we will refactor the router_updated notification with related router id. And let the l3 agent call neutron server (l3 plugin) with specific port id directly after the router setup.

>>>

[1, 2, 3]

>>> a
[1, 2]

[1, 2]

From my personal experiences, when your cloud deployment growth, you will not want to add more agents. But the metering functions are independent, you need to run L3 agent, ovs-agent and metering agent on every compute nodes. You have 1000 compute nodes, you will have 3 * 1000 neutron agents. I see, but that is actually one of the problems I see. It seems to me that we are deprecating it, but the alternative would not fulfill all of its feature. That is why I suggested extending the current API and allowing a different backend to apply the metering rules. Then, we would address your use case with the API that we already have in place.

My idea is to not involve metering API/DB/agent at all. All the L3 IPs metering will be done by L3-agent natively. Neutron will add some default policy which is for the IPs do not have a binding policy. And ensure every L3 IPs have qos policy in order to make L3 agent can install TC rules for the L3 IPs.

Why not re-use the API? I mean, the API is the standard to configure labels and rules. One could add a new option in the API (e.g. driver/backend/something else) that defines the agent where the rules are applied. Then, we could satisfy what you want and keep the API that is already in place and used by everyone else. This would also create a smoother migration path.

After some consideration about the API, IMO, I would not to change or extend those. Here are some reason:
1. save the RPCs between neutron server and agents when the API resource create/delete/update.
2. if there are tons of IPs/Routers/Gateways etc., operators need to call tons of APIs to enable the metering.
3. from my personal experiences, operators usually want all L3 public IPs are under monitor, so config once and funciton up looks a better solution for them.
4. same to 3, but for cloud app developers, current metering API sometimes causes too much developing/operation burden on north APPs, such as console or portal.
5. this spec is to add an alternative for L3 public IPs metering, it is not an extension of existing metering plugin/api/agent.

My final idea is to deprecate the metering agent to narrow down the pressure centrilized MQ and DB when the running hosts have a large number of growth. So it's a bit strange to me if we still remain to use the existing APIs. I will take a look at the metering code deeply. For now, it seems tightly coupled for the metering plugin, notifications, RPCs and agents. Looks we need to do lots refactor works.

why bandwidth capacity? Above You are saying that problem for operators is that users creates many virtual routers which are doing nothing but using resources. And I can agree with that part. But is it bandwidth which is consumed most by such routers? I don't think so.

What will the networking resource consume in network node? It mainly is physical NIC. How to evaluate the NIC capability generally?  It is NIC defined bandwidth specification.

So how to caculate the router used/available bandwidth? Router centralized floating IP bandwidth QoS, or may be with gateway IP bandwidth QoS for centralized SNAT.

We will have config for such NIC bandwidth and ratios, this is very similar to VM cpu, doesn't the host process use the cpu? memory? Such bandwidth should also need prediction and planning.

One more thing. When I'm reading this specs I have feeling that You are describing different problem here and You are trying to solve a bit different problem.
If real problem are routers "which are doing nothing" than resources like memory or cpu might be important also, not only bandwidth.
And if this is really problem for You, maybe much simpler solution would be to change existing scheduler mechanism to do "lazy" scheduling of routers, only when it really have connected some interface. That way routers which are doing nothing will not create namespaces, haproxies and use other resources.

If however problem is with routers which are really consume bandwidth, than it's IMO more complicated problem to solve and we should check how nova are doing it together with placement and do something similar.

Oh, sorry for the late reply. Yes, the lazy schedule and the capacity are different problem. No matter when the scheduling happens, the physical hosts are always has its capacity. This spec is aim to limit the total router amount/bandwidth of a network node. We do not consider the scheduling opportunity, but give the current neutron a chance to limit the running router number on a network node.

The main concern of this spec is to aviod that "your network node has too many routers to work as usual. It can not burden more scheduled routers. Otherwise, the running resources of your network may face the risk of link broken or HA state change."

So this spec will provider two ways to describe the capacity: one is the total number of routers for a single network node you insist;  another is the physical bandwidth of a network node.
You can use some external tools and add new network node if current node will reach some capacity configured by You.
But with Your solution new routers will end up with error "No valid host found" which Nova is famous of already. Is that really better for end user?

For instance, what external tool? Did you mean some monitor daemon? Yes, it can be one way you get the router number of the agent, but you still do not prevent the unlimited router growth.
For that 'new network node' thing, in some cloud life cycle, it usually takes a lot of manpower and time to put a new batch of machines on the shelf. In a standardized process, this usually takes a long time, including some hardware provisioning and testing work etc. When you get the alarm and accomplish the new machines schedule, the router number may have exceeded the threshold.
The argument with many ports and overloaded ovs-agent and/or L3 agent is totally valid and I agree with it.

IMHO, API 'fast failed' is better than created but your system is down, then the resource is not really uesable. New created routers' amount growth can sometimes hurt the running ones. Router related ports are continuously pluged into the ovs-bridge, there will be too many ports on ovs-bridge to process/work properly. You can create 400 router to a network node, then you may see your L3-agent and ovs-agent have no response, or possibly dead.

And for vm it is easy as You know how many cores/ram/disk instance will use in the moment when You want to schedule it. For router it is harder as You don't have this information during router creation and scheduling process.
This proposal is adding that information. A scheduler is a very basic routine for hosting resources based on some capacity.

And I have one extra idea is to limit the floating IP creation under such router with 'total bandwidth'. We can add all the floating IP bandwidth and gateway IP bandwidth. Then compare if the new floating IP will let the total exceed the specification.

specs/wallaby/l3-agent-capacity.rst.message: this is not what was decided and approved in the drivers meeting. Please check https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1828494/comments/10 and update this spec accordingly.

From Your comment it looks like You want to have much more complete "bandwidth aware scheduling" of the routers. In such case I think this spec should be changed and You should consider usage of the placement API for that as this is the goal of that project.
Also You should consider the cases where router can use different physical network so will consume totally different bandwidth than e.g. other routers.
There is also problem that currently L3 agent's aren't aware about bridge mappings and phys nets at all and they should be probably with such feature.
That's why we decided to go with much simpler "max_routers" value for the scheduler as it wouldn't require all those things mentioned by me above.

Please take a look at line 129 [Alternatives], that should be what you guys approved. But IMO, that "routers_max" looks a bit rigid for a large scale cloud deployment. While one agent has only one router, the floating IP's total bandwidth under it may have exceed the maximum of the phyical NIC. More bad thing is that more routers with more floating IPs can still be hosted on this same host. Maybe someday you will raise another attribute "floatingips_max" for router. But the problem is basically same, one floating IP's bandwidth can be set higher. When the number of routers is less than "routers_max", and each router's floating IP number is less than "floatingips_max", the total bandwidth of all floating IPs in this host still exceeds physical device‘s spec.

For this proposal here, it contains three dimensions of bandwidth:
1. the physical NIC's bandwidth
2. the total bandwidth a neutron Router sould serve (here this line proposed)
3. the floating IPs total bandwidth under one Router

So, things will be clear:
1. how many router can a host run is based on the total bandwidth of routers
2. how many floating IPs can a router serve is based on the router's bandwidth attribute (here this line proposed)

So, maybe we can reconsider these problems at the meeting.

we are mixing here things from L2 and L3 agent. IMO L3 agent shouldn't be aware about bridge mappings and bandwidth on each phys interface. L2 agent is already able to report that to placement so we should reuse it if that would be really needed.

tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_update.py.message:
Ok, it took me a while but I finally saw what's going on here. Basically, by changing from returning the whole inventory into returning only the inventory name we are trying to use: ~/tripleo-ansible-inventory.yaml file (which is located in the Undercloud's home directory). Then, when executing the update command, for some reason we point instead to an inventory.yaml local to the mistral container from where the script is triggered:

https://storage.bhs.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_fa0/784416/1/check/tripleo-ci-centos-8-scenario000-multinode-oooq-container-updates-train/fa0e163/logs/undercloud/var/lib/mistral/config-download-latest/ansible-playbook-command.sh

ansible-playbook-3 /var/lib/mistral/990aaa71-2e83-4965-ab30-73a596aad8a4/update_steps_playbook.yaml --limit Controller --module-path /usr/share/ansible-modules --become --become-user root --inventory-file /var/lib/mistral/990aaa71-2e83-4965-ab30-73a596aad8a4/inventory.yaml "$@"

However, if you open that inventory.yaml file, you won't see an inventory..but a reference to ~/tripleo-ansible-inventory.yaml:

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/fa0e163d5d484308a1eed6a8b94fc72a/log/logs/undercloud/var/lib/mistral/config-download-latest/inventory.yaml

Why did this work before? Because in tripleo-common we do the following:

If the content from _inventory is not a file, then it will dump it locally (therefore in the mistral container) under an inventory.yaml file:

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-common/blob/stable/train/tripleo_common/actions/ansible.py#L242-L243

Otherwise, it will dump whatever was in the _inventory parameter, which doesn't seem very correct:

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-common/blob/stable/train/tripleo_common/actions/ansible.py#L242-L243

And this is why we find the inventory.yaml file including a reference to /home/zuul/tripleo-ansible-inventory.yaml

Phew...it took me few neurons..

After talking to Sergii I can see clearly what happened. In this line it's being checked if the inventory is a certain type and if the path exists:

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-common/blob/stable/train/tripleo_common/actions/ansible.py#L445-L446

However, this code is being executed from the mistral executor container and self._inventory points to /home/stack/tripleo-ansible-inventory.yaml which is not available in the container itself. Therefore it moves to the next condition:

        elif not isinstance(self._inventory, six.string_types):
            self._inventory = yaml.safe_dump(self._inventory)

        path = os.path.join(self.work_dir, 'inventory.yaml')

setting self._inventory to "/home/stack/tripleo-ansible-inventory.yaml" and few lines later it drops this content into inventory.yaml file:

        with open(path, 'w') as inventory:
            inventory.write(self._inventory)

        self._inventory = path
        return path

swift/common/ring/ring.py.message:
Seek from the end might not be supported in Python 2.7. I thought I read somewhere it was.. but it's failing for me. Maybe I need to rebuild my 2.7 env :shrug:

If it doens't work in py2, then we can either:

  1. Only allow v2 in py3.
  2. Move v2 to something like bz2 as it apparently supports seeking more efficiently as it's a block based compression rather then stream.
  3. Go a mixed approach where in the meta and index are not gzipped, and only the dev and replica2part2dev BLOBs are.

The current version of this patch will allow py2 to save to v2 but can't load it. Only a py3 can load, and it's because the py2 gzip can't seek from the back.

Hmm, maybe I could always seek forwards, so long as I have an accurate byte count of both the compressed and uncompressed it might be possible. But that would be something like:

  gzip_file.seek(<number 8 from the end>, os.SEEK_START)
  gzip_file.seek(<number 8 + metadata length from the end>, os.SEEK_START)

Or we could just keep it as only load from Py3, so the code stays tidier (only because Py3 only should be just aroud the corner) maybe even before this patch lands?
Another option is to keep the index seperate from the metadata. So the metadata becomes another BLOB in the file. The end just has the index + index size?

I do not think we should extend it.

Nova does not restrict the policy by user_id except keypairs API. We have kept it for a few of the destructive actions (for backwards compatibility) and intent to remove them too in future. I remember we discussed this in 2016 but I could not find the ML thread for that but
the consensus that time was we do not intend to support user_id based restriction permission in the API.

This is the spec where we kept the user_id support for destructive actions and the reason.

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/newton/implemented/user-id-based-policy-enforcement.html

gbpservice/neutron/services/grouppolicy/.message: Just curious - was there a reason that you couldn't use the self._get_router and self._update_router APIs?

It's not clear why explicitly setting routes to an empty set needs to be done here. Was this failing some UT? If so, what was the failure? I'm asking because it seems like we should set a user-specified value, if we're setting it.

Thanks for pointing me to the upstream change that this code is trying to address (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/789929. As a side note: I'm not a fan of this patch in upstream neutron, as it tries to "fix" the user intent. In my mind, if the user set the routes nonsensically, then that's on the user.... but this is already merged upstream, so we have to adapt).  Here's an example of an exception that this code is trying address: https://paste.opendev.org/show/812423/, and here's the test: https://opendev.org/x/group-based-policy/src/branch/master/gbpservice/neutron/tests/unit/services/grouppolicy/test_resource_mapping.py#L1882-L1922. The test creates two external networks/segments, with subnets of 10.10.1/24 and 10.10.2/24, respectively, each with a static route that points to the subnet gateway (10.10.1.1 and 10.10.2.1, respectively). It then creates an L3 policy and connects it to the first external segment (10.10.1/24). It then updates the L3 policy to disconnect it from the first external segment and connect it to the second (10.10.2/24). This is when we hit the route validation exception. My recommendation would be to instead see if you can get rid of the exception by making a fix in this code path needed (e.g. remove some routes?):
https://opendev.org/x/group-based-policy/src/branch/master/gbpservice/neutron/services/grouppolicy/drivers/resource_mapping.py#L2092-L2095. It may be as simple as removing a static route in the router when disconnecting the external segment (note: each L3 policy has mapping to a neutron router).

However, I should point out that some policy drivers in the GBP service plugin (notably the AIM policy driver) have a significant difference in the external networking semantics from neutron: neutron expects each project to only have a single router connected to an external network, whereas GBP allows multiple Layer 3 policies (even within the same project) to be connected multiple external segments. This may mean that we have to make additional fixes specific to some GBP policy-drivers. That said, let's start with the first fix, and see what other issues are uncovered.

I have a reproduction test for the first half of this issue in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/820540

It would be nice to extend that with the revert step to observe the second issue as well.

I'm wonder if this move has any unwanted side effect. I.e. finish_resize sets the instance.flavor = new_flavor during a resize today but you move applying the migration context earlier. Also if there is a failure and the migration / resize is reverted then the migration context needs to be reverted too. Have you checked that by moving the applying earlier still makes the revert consistent?

I share the same concern for the unwanted side-effects, since the apply_migration_context is saved in this case, so it may impact other unseen areas of the code which may use this information.

Regarding the revert, I believe both changes should have the same effect. I've checked that the revert was fixed by this change by forcing the task to run at the beginning of finish_resize, before the update to the instance is performed.

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/820549
Thanks for pointing it out, will check.

Honestly, I prefer https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/820549/1/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py as it uses the RT for tracking the instances every periodic time.

What we *could* do is merging first gibi's change and verifying whether we also need to merge this change, but I don't think we need it but maybe I'm wrong

Hm, strange coincidence that we both got hit by the same issue around the same time. Anyhow. I agree that we saw the same problem. So the two bugs are duplicates. I will mark the newer one as duplicate in launchpad. 

The two patches represents two possible solutions for the same issue:

* your patch attacks it from the resize codepath perspective. And moves the applying of the migration context from finish_resize to resize_instance. This change is observable by other parallel processes as the instance object changes are saved. And it moves that apply call from the source host to the destination host. 

* mine [1] attacks it from the other racing entity the periodic job. During the periodic job it temporarily and locally applies the migration context to an instances that are in the intermittent post-migration status to keep the resource accounting on the destination correct. 

@Reviewers: how do you feel which direction we should go?

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/820549/1

I agree that both issues seem to be the same too. I believe https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/820549/1/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py should also work, since it fixes the instance topology inside the resource tracker before it updates the resources for the instance. It has the benefit of also making the change locally, so it has less potential for impact in unexpected areas.
I'd prefer to wait for https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/820549 to be merged first before seeing whether we need to also merge this one.
I agree with this approach. Since the change on resource_tracker does not save the instance, it seems to be less potentially impactful, so we may try it first.

blazarnova/scheduler/filters/blazar_filt.message: It may be only triggered by unit tests when the aggregate object is incompletely mocked. But it's safer this way.

If for some reason the aggregate pool and the preemptible pool are set to the same name, the aggregate will get added to the pools list twice, which I think may cause weird behavior later on when the length of the pools object is checked. Maybe it should be a set, or the existence of the aggregate should be checked before inserting again? Or, maybe this is an invalid configuration, at which point it could issue a warning?
Using the same name would allow using the freepool directly (with support in Blazar for the same approach). I will update.
I updated the patch and reverted to use the freepool by default. Additional features linked to the use of a dedicated preemptibles aggregate will come in separate patches.

Should FLAVOR_PREEMPTIBLE also be a configurable flavor name? It seems that the operator would have to create a new flavor if they want to use this, would it be convenient for them to designate an existing flavor instead?

FLAVOR_PREEMPTIBLE is the name of a property that can be added onto any flavor. Nova doesn't allow customise property names used by the scheduler (for example aggregate_instance_extra_specs), I went with the same approach.

A check for explicit length of 1 is good b/c it's safer, but under what circumstances would this be of length > 1? Feels like that's the result of a bug. Not a comment for here perhaps, but I think there's a case for a periodic task in Blazar that performs cleanup on aggregate state to get around this. Otherwise there will be a host in the freepool but it won't be getting scheduled for preemptibles (b/c it's also in another aggregate), and this will be far from obvious to the operator.

I think this was future-proofing for instance reservation support: in instance reservation mode, hosts are both in the freepool and in reservation aggregates.

However I just tested and realised that fetch_blazar_pools() filters aggregates with blazar_az_prefix, causing only physical reservation aggregates to be included.

debian-mirror-tools/config/debian/common.message:
Sure, there were a few thoughts behind my thinking. First being that if you look at packages installed on a Debian system you will note that the version/revisions of linux-image and linux-libc-dev match

dpkg -l | grep -e "linux-image\|linux-libc-dev"
ii  linux-image-5.10.0-11-amd64                   5.10.92-1                              amd64        Linux 5.10 for 64-bit PCs (signed)
ii  linux-image-amd64                             5.10.92-1                              amd64        Linux for 64-bit PCs (meta-package)
ii  linux-libc-dev:amd64                          5.10.92-1                              amd64        Linux support headers for userspace development


Second the packaging scripts included with the mainline kernel, that you use to run commands such as 'make deb-pkg' produce the linux-libc-dev package along with the image and headers.

When you look for answers on this you unfortunately find contradictory information or lack of information. Such as this

https://askubuntu.com/questions/1120965/multiple-custom-kernels-vs-linux-libc-dev

In the end I really think it comes down to usecase. We do not have a policy saying that uapi files can't be patched, so we must install a new linux-libc-dev or risk the change not being reflected in the userspace headers. In reality the chances of our kernel source having a change in uapi files compared to the Debian kernel source is small to nil, so what we decide here is of no consequence. If anything a tool to review the existing linux-libc-dev contents (Debian) vs. the built linux-libc-dev contents would be the way to go, then a change which would affect libc itself could potentially be caught.

Hi Mark and Li,

My understanding is that linux-libc-dev needs to match the installed glibc package, and not the kernel that the user is currently running. Is my understanding incorrect? I recall the following quote from [1]:

```
Do NOT use the /usr/src/linux area! This area has a (usually incomplete) set of kernel headers that are used by the library header files. They should match the library, and not get messed up by whatever the kernel-du-jour happens to be.
```

(Yes, it is referring to /usr/src/linux and not /usr/include/linux, but I think that is a historical left-over.)

Here is another relevant link: [2]

Mark, could you share your findings about this topic, please? I am curious as to what you found as well.

[1] https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/admin-guide/README.html#installing-the-kernel-source

[2] https://stackoverflow.com/a/9094467

About linux-libc-dev and its content, please refer to: 
https://debian.pkgs.org/11/debian-main-amd64/linux-libc-dev_5.10.84-1_amd64.deb.html
I believe the content comes from kernel source.
OK. I was reading a bit more on Debian custom kernels and this seems to be common. Thanks for the additional detail.

Understood, thank you. I found a few more references that appear to support my original statement (i.e., linux-libc-dev should match the headers used at glibc's build time), but I could not find out why Debian chooses to uprevision linux-libc-dev with every kernel update. (Ubuntu does not appear to do this, for the record.)

In the end though, I agree with your point regarding "our use-case", because if we do not use our custom-built version of linux-libc-dev, then I do not think that we will be able to make use of CONFIG_SIGEXIT (i.e., the notification of death feature) in StarlingX, because the API for this feature is made available in ``/usr/include/linux/prctl.h``, which would be in linux-libc-dev.

Here are the additional references I found:

[1] https://lists.yoctoproject.org/g/yocto/topic/64460477
[2] https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/kbuild/headers_install.html
[3] https://kernelnewbies.org/KernelHeaders
Linux-libc-dev will be replaced by the one we compile from linux source. So drop the one downloaded from debian source.

We are only dropping the -dev package though, this seems odd. And why do we need to rebuild libc? this is not tied to the kernel in a way that this needs to be done and will have impact on all of the userspace applications. Please describe exactly why libc needs to be affected in any way due to us using a different kernel source.

linux-image-5.10.0-6-amd64-unsigned is the name of the kernel package we build from source. The complete package name with version num is linux-image-5.10.0-6-amd64-unsigned_5.10.74-1.stx.1_amd64.deb. We do this following debian, and please refer to https://packages.debian.org/bullseye/linux-image-5.10.0-9-amd64-unsigned.
Ah OK. I actually switched my laptop to Debian over the holidays and I can confirm that this is correct. Thanks for the explanation.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Are there any instances in which localhost will not be the hostname required?

So the registry is usually accessed using something like "undercloud.ctlplane" or some other fancy, computer generated FQDN.
The "localhost" here is to ensure the "uri" module is working - but we could inject whatever name we want in the /etc/hosts and use it.

The replace as proposed should also allow to support any update to the vhost content, especially if we're going back to an actual hostname. But in such case, we'd need to inject that hostname in the /etc/hosts during the molecule preparation task. Or something like that.

Possibly. But only hostnames consisting of exactly one '*' char will be impacted by this change. The httpd config we are validating is only defining the listening behavior. We can't really check if the machine listens to any arbitrary address, so we use localhost instead.

Agreed that it's a little hairy, but I think it's about as clear as we could hope for. About the only changes I could think of would be

- dropping the "is_success(resp.status_int)", since "resp_record_type == 'shard'" should only ever be true of successful responses;
- moving the "and not cached_results" into the "resp_record_type == 'shard'" clause, since we'll never serve the failure from cache; and
- ahead of the if, defining something like

Right; so it's "maybe" because we're only looking at the request so far. I can't quite articulate why, but I feel like "may_be_shard_listing" might be a better name.

I think the point is more that info suggested that the container was sharded, and the request failed -- at that point, we have no way of knowing the container isn't sharded, we have to just assume it was based on cache.

There's also the possibility that info suggests the container is sharded, but when we make the (successful!) backend request *we discover it isn't*. At the moment, that would still increment shard_listing.backend.200 -- though I'm not convinced that that's *wrong* exactly... or maybe we want my suggestion above to be more like

 if may_be_shard_listing and (
         (not is_success(resp.status_int) and expected_sharded_container)

> I think the point is more that info suggested that the container was sharded, and the request failed -- at that point, we have no way of knowing the container isn't sharded, we have to just assume it was based on cache.

@Clay @Tim thanks for your feedback and suggestions, I took stab at making this easier to grok (?) but obvs it is less compact :)

We'll get failure metrics as long as

* shard ranges *weren't* in  cache, so we had to go to the backend to get them,
* that request failed, but
* container *info* is in cache, and indicates the container is sharded

Keeping container info in cache may get interesting, of course -- it's got a much shorter cache time, but it should also be a lot cheaper to get from the backend.

So it seems we'll only ever see bad status metrics if the shards are cached then? Makes sense. It's the kind of info though that would be good to write somewhere, something useful for ops. Do we have doc anywhere for metrics.

So we can only get non success metrics if there was 1 successful shard ranges GET before it failed and before it TTLs out of memcache. Totally understand why, but does mean we'd might see a spike until the good TTLs out and then we don't see the error numbers spike anymore, and that might be good to know.

Not a blocker from my POV, this is _much_ better then what we currently have. Just one of those things that's good to understand and might easily be forgotten (by me) :P

Putting -W as we need one more change here after reviewing [1].
Instead of building a new, fresh playbook (and a separated Ceph command), let's extend the existing cli (overcloud ceph deploy), embedding the VIP(s) creation (when we need them) during the ceph_nfs deployment.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/ta.message: So here you use the new parameter you added by modifying the tripleo_service_vip module.

Yes, this parameter is used to produce, on the specified "rendered_path", a yaml file containing the mapping between the service and the reserved vip.
For ceph-nfs purposes it's not useful, as we're deploying this daemon before the overcloud is created, but, for instance, it can be useful to build an ingress for ceph_rgw (which is still deployed during the overcloud).

So you're assuming that something like 'storage_cloud_0_subnet' will exist within the rest of the deployment? What if it doesn't exist? 

I see the examples in the module use it. I wonder if we should document that it's required that the _subnet should be defined in the networkv2 file.

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/825502/8/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/tripleo_service_vip.py#89

ack, that makes sense, I didn't thought about that kind of scenario.
At this point, in my next PS, I'm going to introduce two different way of building VIPs:
- subnet based vip: it's reserved from the subnet/network passed as input
- fixed_ip vip: on the specified network, the operator can reserve the specified VIP.

Of course this brings other requirements:
- a flag to select which mode you want the module to work with
- a few sanity checks on the user input: e.g, if fixed_ip mode is selected, we should fail if one of the ceph services has no entry! Same story for subnet, and yes, the '_subnet' suffix can be used as a default value. By doing this we can provide a subnet if it has a different name.
As an example, somthing like the following is allowed:

---
fixed: true
ceph_services:
  - service: ceph_nfs
    network: storage_cloud_0
    ip_address: 172.16.11.159
  - service: ceph_rgw
    network: storage_cloud_0
    subnet: storage_cloud_0_subnet
    ip_address: 172.16.11.160

I'm going to update release notes on [1] and start a doc change that describes the new parameter and the allowed input combinations.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/825679/4/releasenotes/notes/ceph_vip_provisioning-dcac72d62c70c57c.yaml

In general if a network is created, the corresponding <network>_subnet is allocated.
As per release-notes (and the doc change we have to create as a follow up of this patch) [1], the mapping between the ceph service and the network should be provided by the operators (ceph_nfs, for instance, can use a composable network as the frontend network, and this info can't be automatically gathered at this stage).

Had a discussion about the format with danpb [1]. Initially I restricted the set of characters to alphanumeric as the PCI/PCIe specs say, however, the vendors themselves violate this with punctuation and other printable characters.

In the end, danpb suggested allowing printable characters only instead of trying to enforce alphanumeric ones. The spec does not have concrete ranges or tables besides the verbal description saying "alphanumeric" so we stick with printable ASCII code points now [2].

One example he had for non-NIC PCI devices was some HPE component that had "N/A" printed instead of a serial number.

Encountering a NIC with "N/A" for a serial number is subjectively unlikely for NICs (engineering samples I've seen do not have a VPD at all).

We cannot statically (based on the value alone) or dynamically (via a vendor's manufacturing DB) validate uniqueness of a serial number much like with UUIDs. In this case we trust them to be unique because the PCI/PCIe specs require them to be unique and we trust Libvirt to read the right thing.

Duplicate serial numbers on different NICs (manufacturing error) is another interesting possibility but I think Neutron should handle that when querying an OVN chassis hostname based on a serial number. From the operational standpoint, if such case is encountered, the offending NIC should be RMA-ed.

As we discussed in the early iterations of the spec, there is a possibility that a single DPU would service multiple compute nodes in a blade server in which case they would see the same serial number. Which means Nova should not do anything about multiple compute hosts seeing a device with the same serial.

In summary: I think we should treat it as a vendor-specific opaque string and trust its uniqueness. Since Libvirt enforces printable ASCII we could do that here too but Libvirt produces utf-8 encoded XML so we would be testing that Libvirt did not break.

The max VPD field value length per the PCI/PCIe spec is 255 bytes (because the length is encoded in 1 byte) so we have a size limit here as well in case we want to enforce it.


[1] https://listman.redhat.com/archives/libvir-list/2021-October/msg01076.html
[2] https://gitlab.com/libvirt/libvirt/-/blob/ad8ba5b1/src/util/virpcivpd.c#L193
[3] https://libvirt.org/formatnode.html#VPDCap

The bug you are referring to is probably https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1915255 which is about VFs with PFs that are not netdevs.

Looking at the code again, I can see that Nova currently classifies devices as having `dev_type == SRIOV_VF` only if they have the 'phys_function' capability AND if there is a parent PF address present:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/a6ef502/nova/virt/libvirt/host.py#L1261-L1264
>                if (
>                    fun_cap.type == 'phys_function' and
>                    len(fun_cap.device_addrs) != 0
>                ):
>                    phys_address = "%04x:%02x:%02x.%01x" % (
>                        fun_cap.device_addrs[0][0],
>                        fun_cap.device_addrs[0][1],
>                        fun_cap.device_addrs[0][2],
>                        fun_cap.device_addrs[0][3])
>                    result = {
>                        'dev_type': fields.PciDeviceType.SRIOV_VF,
>                        'parent_addr': phys_address,
>                    }

Otherwise the device will end up being a "type-PCI" one and the code path in question will not be hit.

So we always know that if a device type is VF then there is always a parent_addr populated based on the address data provided in the phys_function capability.

As a side note, it's easy to confuse the parent PCIe address in Libvirt XML which is not the same as the parent PF PCIe address.

I will leave the check for now but since there is no way to generate a device XML that would trigger it, I am open to removing it completely.

a user sends a PUT request with {'foo': 'bar'}.

1：admin user,      metadata contains admin_only_metadata
2：admin user,      metadata not contains admin_only_metadata
3: not admin user,  metadata contains admin_only_metadata
4: not admin user,  metadata not contains admin_only_metadata

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Does this relate to https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/811247 and if so how?
This is about listing the in-progress uploads. The prior patch was about listing the parts in a given upload.

If I understand the multipart parts listings bug correctly the issue was mostly about the ordering of segments 1, 10, 2, 20, 3, 30

This change seems to be more about skipping over enough segments to find enough of the uploads... 

... but I'm worried it's making a significant number of requests to page through all the segments, that's a lot of CPU doing [de]serialization sqlite->json->http->proxy and also all that etag decryption just to throw it away.

Wish I had a better idea!  (custom code in the container server to do prefix/delim style skip queries that are segment aware!?  might be something to think about for ALO...)

Would some additional test stubs be useful to you?

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/814189

We've been running with this in prod for a while. The (potentially many, *many*) extra backend requests aren't great, but it seems better than returning incorrect results. At least clients can limit results (and as a result, backend requests) with things like key-marker, prefix, and max-uploads.

This definitely highlights a design limitation to think about if/when we implement a more MPU-like Swift-native large object.

swift/common/wsgi.py.message: Strictly speaking there is only one app in the pipeline, the rest are middleware, so probably could just be `_pipeline_app` but final definitely get's rid of any ambiguity 😊

Depends on how you look at it 😉

My (simplified) read on the PEP is that

* an application is just a callable that takes an env and start_response function and returns some iterable of byte strings after calling start_response,
* a server is something that invokes such an application, and
* a middleware is an application on one side and a server on another

so each middleware could fairly be called an application.
filter is a builtin function - pls use a different name

IIRC this wrapping of create does prevent some duplicated log messages on start up

confirmed on master we still loadapp twice; but w/o this when call ctx.create() below we'll get it twice per call (i.e. log 4 times intead of "just" 2 times)

N.B. this change returns app and doesn't call create again; so we still get startup logging messages just twice
